text: Well, New Orleans was actually the only
place in the United States where the
African slaves were allowed to keep
their drum tradition. They played in a
place called Congo Square. The most
important aspect of African drumming for
jazz musicians is the way the
improvisation is organized. There's
generally some type of high rhythm
called the bell rhythm. Ding ding ding
ding ding ding ding ding ding ding ding
ding. And everybody can hear that
rhythm. Then there's a lower
rhythm. Then the middle rhythm will be
the person that
improvises. These things together, this
form of improvisation became a part of
jazz.
[Applause]
That's one very important aspect of
African music. Another important aspect
of African music that the jazz musician
inherited is the prevalence of ritual
and the importance of ritual. So we have
these two worlds colliding. One the
African world where a pe a a part might
be played 200 years the same way but
very little change. So the ritual is
important. It reminds you of who you are
and it wards off evil spirits. It gives
you comfort and it lets you know that
you can fend off whatever is in the
environment that's disturbing you. Then
we have the European focus on evolution.
So when those two things that appear to
be opposites come together, we have
jazz.
